```{r setup}
library(luciole)
```


## ggplot2

Add Luciole font with:

```{r add_luciole}
add_luciole()
```


Then declare the `"Luciole"` family in your graphics:

```{r ggplot2}
library(ggplot2)
ggplot() +
  aes(0, 0, label = "lisibilit√©") +
  geom_text(size = 20, family = "Luciole") + 
  theme_grey(base_family = "Luciole")
```




## Shiny

Load Luciole CSS file into your page with:

```{r luciole_font, eval=FALSE}
luciole_font_dependency()
```

By default a style tag is injected in the head of the page to use Luciole in he whole body.

Example:

```{r shiny, eval=FALSE}
library(shiny)

ui <- fluidPage(
  
  luciole_font_dependency(),
  
  tags$h2("Hello, I'm using Luciole font to improve lisibility.")
)

server <- function(input, output, session) {
  
}

shinyApp(ui, server)
```
